oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Endotoxic Shock in the Dog: Effects of Allopourinol, Catalase, and Superoxide Dismutase
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Novotny, M. J.
Laughlin, M. H.
Adams, H. R.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: endotoxicosis
oxygen-derived free radicals
E. coli
allopurinol
catalase
superoxide dismutase
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The hypothesis of the current study is if free radical mechanisms represented by this pathway (Fig. 1) are important to endotoxicosis, then these pharmacoenzymatic drugs should be beneficial. The specific objective of this study was to determine evidence for a role of oxygen-derived free radicals during the developmental phase of E. coli endotoxic shock. The effects of three agents, allopurinol, catalase, and superoxide dismutase, on the hemodynamic and respiratory changes that occur during acute endotoxemia were studied.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: AAVPT Biennial Symposia; Fifth Biennial Symposium; 154-165
